title: borders-book-festival-jonathon-porritt-talks-climate-change
story: THIS Sundaysees environmentalist and writer Jonathon Porritt joining the Borders Book Festivals online audience to talk about his latest book, Hope In Hell: A Decade To Confront The Climate Emergency.Porritt, , is one of the UKs leading environmental activists, whose roles have included chair of The Ecology Party , director of Friends of the Earth, and co-founder of Forum for the Future, a sustainable development charity.Author of nine other books, Porritt hopes his latestwill reach "a combination of dferent audiences", the most important of which, he says, is the young people who are inheriting the impacts of manmade climate change."My sense today is that young people are the ones who are really going to suffer most from the accelerating climate impacts that we are now witnessing," Porritt tells the Border , "and every single day for the whole of the rest of their lives will in one way or another be impacted by climate change."He adds: "I talk a lot in the book about what I call intergenerational injustice how one generation has basically made it practically impossible for the next generation to have the same prospects, the same expectations, the same hopes as previous generations have had."The book, which stresses the urgency of fighting climate change, is also aimed at the "weary environmentalists" who have "been plugging away" at campaigning and those, says Porritt, "who have no pre-existing knowledge or deep understanding of climate change, who I hope will be able to get stuck in really quickly and pick up everything they need to know within the first four chapters."Porritt has little time for the idea that human activity might not have had an impact on climate change, or that the subject is over-egged by the media or environmental activists.He says: "I dont believe there is any serious continuing debate about whether climate change is happening or whether its caused by our lestyles or our economy and I think theres less and less of a debate about it not being serious."I think thats symptomatic of a change going on in peoples minds because they can see the impacts of climate change."The veteran campaigner believes that any failure of iniduals to change their behaviour is not down to climate change denial but what he calls "disavowal" ndash "As in, I see this is happening but perhaps Im not the person who can make a dference, so I will continue to be a bystander rather than an active participant in addressing this challengersquo," says Porritt."The story of the next decade is getting more and more people to come away from that bystander role and to be prepared to get stuck in."And Porritt believes this "disavowal" is part of the reason governments can be slow to enact policies to combat climate change."Thats what makes it possible for the politicians to go on downgrading the signicance of climate change," he says.ldquoOur politicians are not in denial but they are absolutely not addressing it as the emergency that the science now tells us it is."And you can see that in the policies they brought forward in response to the pandemic ndash the build back better movement has actually just become build build build."The UK governments "classic failure of deeper political understanding" is one reason the countrys economy struggled during lockdown, believes Porritt.He says: "Instead of using this as a fantastic opportunity to show how we could have an economy that is prosperous but very low carbon all were doing is defaulting to exactly the same kind of policy growth band positions that we were in before COVID."Having had this shock, this really traumatic impact on our expectations of what a good le looks like, its incumbent on us to learn that lesson, and use it to help shape a more resilient and compassionate economy, one that is more mindful of environmental stewardship obligations for ourselves as well as future generations."And it is the future generations who Porritt sees pushing for change.He says: "It was so interesting when Greta Thunberg was here in the UK. I think it was Michael Gove who said, Your example gives us hope. And she instantly responded and said, We dont want your hope, we want clear, cost-effective but very radical policy responses to the climate change. We dont want you to be hopeful on our behalf, we want you to be active on our behalfrsquo.He concludes: "Would you not be annoyedyou were a young person who was suddenly confronted by the reality of climate change ldquoOnly to hear politicians say, Well, its dficult to address this, I think this is a challenge for future generations."It makes me feel pretty mad even at the advanced age of , when I hear politicians talking like that ndash its so complacent, its so self-indulgent, its so contemptuous of the interests of young people today."To see in Jonathon Porritt in conversation with journalist and broadcaster Sheena McDonald, go to bordersbookfestival.org online-event jonathon-porritt-hope-in-hellThe Borders Book Festival is sponsored by Baillie Gford.

title: craig-lowrie-completes-fundraiser-memory-late-sister
story: GALASHIELS man Craig Lowrie has completed his fundraising challenge ndash and he says the donations total is ldquounbelievable.Mr Lowrie has now run a dozen km runs during the Border summer festival season, having completed his final event in Coldstream on Friday ."It was always going to be an emotional run as it was the last one," said Mr Lowrie, of Selkirk, whose son Robbie was last yearrsquos Braw Lad in Galashiels.The challenge was created after this yearrsquos festivals were cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.Around pound, has been raised, according to Mr Lowrie, with the money going to the festival committees, as well as the Borders General Hospital.However, Mr Lowrie dedicated his efforts to his late sister, Donna Cameron, of Innerleithen, who died in a road collision last year, just two weeks before her nephews appearance as Braw Lad.Following the completion of the runs, Mr Lowrie said: "It was good to get them finished ndash the running was the easy bit.Reflecting on Fridayrsquos event, he added: "My sisters kids and husband were coming down, and apart from Innerleithen they had not been to any of the other runs."Mr Lowrie was due to be joined by his son in Coldstream, but Robbie had an injury which left him on crutches.But Mr Lowrie didnt run his last challenge alone ndash former Selkirk Standard Bearer Rory Monks joined in."Rory stepped forward to run with me," said Mr Lowrie. "I was glad to have the company as on my own it would have been gruelling."At the time of going to print, Mr Lowrie estimated that his fundraiser had reached a total of around pound, - with just over pound, being raised through his online Go Fund Me page."Its phenomenal, said Mr Lowrie. "I sat with Robbie at the beginning of the summer to talk about it."I didnt expect anything near what weve done ndash its unbelievable."Once he had completed his mammoth task, racking up more  kilometres across the summer, Mr Lowrie gave a speech to supporters through a Facebook livestream.In his speech, Mr Lowrie said: "Especially in these uncertain times we live in, you made the dference ndash I only ran."The comments you guys have posted each week ndash some heartfelt, some really encouraging, some quite funny ndash all really did mean a lot to me and gave me a great sense of pride."To support Craig Lowries fundraiser, visit his Go Fund Me page.

title: galashiels-pavilion-cinema-reveals-date-reopening
story: THE Pavilion Cinema in Galashiels will reopen to the public next week.The Market Street venue has been closed for the last five months due to the coronavirus pandemic.But film lovers will be able tonext Friday .Cinema manager Andrew Poole said: ldquoThe past few months have been the longest and hardest in our familyrsquos  years in running cinemas."But we have survived and we are ready to reopen, albeit under extraordinarily dficult conditions."When we reopen, we will have a range of measures in place to protect our customers including fewer performances to allow deeper cleaning of halls between shows, one-way systems at the concessions stand, perspex screens, hand sanitiser stations throughout the building and we will be adhering to the physical distancing rules in place at that time."We are able to ensure our customers are sat two metres apart in the cinema hall using our booking system."All customers are encouraged to book in advance, but tickets will be available at the cinema."Classic films will be shown at first, before Christopher Nolans Tenetis screened on August .Mr Poole added: "Films such as Peter Rabbit, Jumanji, The Greatest Showmanand Harry Potterwill play alongside Disneyrsquos Onwardwhich had only been showing for a week before we closed."We will also be showing Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back, currently celebrating its th anniversary."We havenrsquot been idle during lockdown. Wersquove carried out some refurbishment works including some repainting, and wersquove also just completed our pound, audio replacement project, replacing our entire audio system including sound processors, ampliers and speakers, upgrading to Dolby . surround sound."And wersquove installed the Dolby Fidelio system to improve access to film for customers who are hard of hearing or visually impaired."The cinema is also launching a Movie Party hall hire scheme, where groups of up to  can enjoy a film privately.Mr Poole said: "After five months of watching films on living room TVs, wersquore confident that our customers will be desperate to get out the house and see films on the big screen once again. Films are made to be watched in cinemas."And with the safety measures we will have in place, we think our customers will feel safe enjoying films where they are best viewed."

title: melrose-rugby-coaches-complete-41-mile-fundraiser
story: MELROSE rugby coaches completed a -mile exercise challenge at the weekend.Bruce Ruthven, Nicholas Alston and Blair Roden travelled from Moffat to Melrose on Saturdayby running, swimming, kayaking and cycling.The trio collected more than pound, for the Move With Mark fundraiser, launched in June by Lachlan Gaddie and his sister Hannahafter their father Mark was diagnosed with cancer.ldquoWersquore really delighted with how the whole day went, said Ruthven, Melrose RFCrsquos head coach.The Move With Mark challenge has now generated more than pound,, with donations going to the Borders General Hospitaland the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh.Car salesman Mark Gaddie, of Melrose, has been receiving treatment at the Edinburgh hospital five times a week. It comes a decade on from his wersquos death from cancer in the BGH.As part of the Move With Mark challenge, Lachlan and Hannah have each been covering . miles every day ndash and they have encouraged others to cover the same distance by swimming, running, cycling or rowing.Yet on Saturday, Ruthven, Alstonand Rodenstepped up to the plate and decided to set themselves the task of covering  miles.Beginning at Moffat Rugby Clubrsquos ground at am, they ran  miles to St Maryrsquos Loch.They then completed a one-mile kayak, followed by a -metre open swim and, lastly, a -mile cycle to Melrose via Selkirk and Abbotsford.ldquoWe had the run finished by .am, so we had probably the toughest part of the day out the way by lunchtime and then the rest of the day was really quite pleasant, said Ruthven, who lives in Peebles.The journey went by without a hitch, according to Ruthven, who expressed gratitude to the grouprsquos -strong ldquosupport team, as well as the dozens of well-wishers lining the route.ldquoThere must have been close to  people throughout the day following us, which really helped, said Ruthven.ldquoTheyrsquore quite winding and twisting roads but we had no issues whatsoever ndash it went really smoothly.He added: ldquoWe managed to complete the  miles in about six hours, which was the time we were aiming for.Ruthven said he came up with the challenge because of his desire to help Hannah and Lachlan. Lachlan plays rugby for Melrose.ldquoIt was really just to support Hannah and Lachlan who are going through a challenging and dficult time, said Ruthven.ldquoThe whole club got behind the challenge and Irsquod like to think thatrsquos a sign of things to come for Melrose Rugby Club. The support we had was overwhelming at times.To donate to the fundraising site set up by Ruthven, Alston and Roden, you can visit the lsquoMoffat to Melrosersquo page on JustGiving

title: eat-help-scotland---interactive-map-shows-50-discount-near

title: scotlands-schools-return-four-simple-tips-help-young-people-sleep
story: A charity has outlined four simple tips to help children and young people get to sleep now they have ed to school.For thousands of people across the country, this week marks their first time in a classroom since March.And with the pressures of ing to school and the drastic change from lockdown le, many might find it hard to fall asleep.Sleep Scotland, a charity organisation working to address sleep issues in children and young people, says that lockdown has resulted in youngsters experiencing poor sleep.Schools are back in Scotland this weekldquoThere are many factors affecting sleep but a crucial one is our Circadian rhythms, they said.ldquoOur circadian rhythms are the physical, mental and behavioural changes that follow a daily cycle.ldquoNearly every cell and tissue has its own rhythm, controlled by our biological clocks.ldquoIf our biological clocks are disrupted it can affect our circadian rhythms, and these changes have been linked to lots of other issues, including over activity, depression and obesity.They have set out four important factors for parents to pay attention to, in order to get your childrsquos sleep back on track for theto school.The four tips:Light#According to Sleep Scotland exposure to light at the wrong time can sht sleep and wakefulness - causing your brain to be alert.Their guidance says: "Make sure your room at bedtime is dark. Reduce light from the hall. Make sure there are no electronics sending out light e.g. a digital alarm clock with a lit display, sleep buttons on equipment etc."You may want to put black curtains at the window or wear an eye mask to limit the light getting into the eye."Sleep Scotland suggests wearing an eye maskOn the other end, you should also get lots of light in the morning to help you feel awake and alert.They added: "Exposure to light at the right time helps keep the circadian clock on the correct time schedule."Make sure you open the curtains and turn on the lightsyou need to. Going for a walk is a great way to start the day."RoutineIt is only natural that during lockdown many of us have found that we have lost our routine and have been staying up later and lying in bed longer in the morning.Sleep Scotland said: "Your body clock works best when you stick to a schedule."In an ideal world, yoursquoll go to sleep and wake up within a half hour of the same time each day, even on weekends."The routines of the day also give us powerful signals and demands that the body remain alert for certain tasks and events."Regular waking and bed times, alongside regular meal times are very important for regulating your body and its s."Sleep PressureSleep pressure is the term used to describe the feeling of tiredness we have, due to the activity we undertake through the day.,params: .pushSleep Scotland say it is important to be active in order to make sure we create the sleep pressure and drowsiness that will help us to fall asleep.They argue that having a nap can relieve our sleep pressure, meaning we find it harder to fall asleep at bedtime.Take a tech breakNaturally during lockdown many of us have resorted to using screens to help keep us entertained,to work and to socialise with friends.And while most modern tech has a blue light filter, it does not filter all light.More importantly, the things you do online are usually things that stimulate your brain and make it harder to turn off when you get into bed.Therefore, Sleep Scotland say you should unplug from all screens at least an hour before bedtime.They added: "In the hour before bed, ensure you focus on doing things that are calming."Now is the time to read, draw, do some calming exercises, have a warm bath etchellip"

title: selkirk-needs-20mph-speed-limit
story: A MPH speed limit should be introduced in Selkirk, according to some community councillors.During a video-conference meeting on Monday , Selkirk Community Council members discussed ways to reduce speeding in the town.David Deacon said: "We need to do something, rather than just talking."Treasurer Judith Thompson expressed interest in Selkirk becoming a ldquorsquos Plenty town.The national campaign, s Plenty For Us, aims to reduce speeds in residential and urban streets to mph.Community council secretary Kirsty Lovatt explained that she had previously been part of a similar campaign.She said she hoped s Plenty would be introduced in the town as it has "so many built up areas".Ms Lovatt also revealed that when she had previously begun the process of introducing the traffic measure, she was advised that it was unlikely to be possible in Selkirk.She said: "I was told it was too expensive to introduce new signage."During Mondayrsquos meeting, members all appeared to agree with the sentiment that there is a speeding issue in the town.And Scottish Borders Council representative Caroline Cochrane, who represents Selkirkshire, said: "Fleece Corner [A] is always a bad one [for speeding]."It was then proposed by Ms Cochrane that a stall be included in the next Selkirk Farmers Market, to be held on September , to gauge interest in supporting the move to a mph zone throughout the town.The community council agreed to work on the creation of a town petition ready for public viewing.

title: john-swinneys-sqa-u-turn-seven-things-need-know
story: John Swinney has announced today that the Scottish Governmentwill abandon the downgrade of more than , exams, with original teacher estimates insteadbeing used to determine this yearrsquos results.The Education Secretary announced the U-turn after a backlash from students who felt they had been treated unfairly by the Scottish Qualications Authoritywhen it recalculated their results.John Swinney said he knew that the apology was not enough, and action would need to be taken to recty the situation.Here are seven things you need to know from his announcement:Teachers estimates to be restored:All downgraded marks will be restored and new certicates sent out.Mr Swinney said: ldquoUsing powers available to me in the EducationAct , I am today directing the SQA to re-issue those awards based solely on teacher or lecturer judgment.ldquoSchools will be able to confirm the estimates they provided for pupils to those that are ing to school this week and next.ldquoThe SQA will issue fresh certicates to affected candidates as soon as possible and, importantly, will inform Ucas and other admission bodies of the new grades as soon as practical in the coming days to allow for applications to college and university to be progressed.What are the new Scottish results The A to C attainment rates for National , Higher and Advanced Higher are now expected to jump by ., . and . percentage points compared to , rising to .%, .% and .% respectively.Will any grades be lowered The Education Secretary has said that no grades which were moderated to give an increased mark will be reduced.When will the results be given John Swinney said that schools will be able to confirm the estimates they provided for pupils to those that are ing to school this week and next.He added: "The SQA will issue fresh certicates to affected candidates as soon as possible and, importantly, will inform UCAS and other admission bodies of the new grades as soon as practical in the coming days to allow for applications to college and university to be progressed.Will all students get into their course Mr Swinney has said that due to the unique circumstances of this situation the Scottish Government ldquowill make provision for enough places in universities and colleges to ensure that no-one is crowded out of a place they would otherwise have been awarded."WhatI have already appealed Pupils, who had been encouraged to appeal their downgrades, will get their new results automatically, although appeals will still be possibledesired.What will lessons from the process of awarding qualications this year that will help to inform any future actions."He also said that an investigation will be undertaken to look at how this yearrsquos awards were handed out.He said: ldquoCoronavirus has not gone away and, while we expect next yearrsquos exams to go ahead, we need to put in place the right plans to make sure we donrsquot find ourselves in the same situation again.Mr Swinney announced that a ldquorapid consultation exercise with teachers will start this week, looking at removing parts of course assessment and adjusting the volume of evidence required in coursework.This report is to be expected within the next five weeks.

title: perseid-meteor-shower-2020-peak-week-best-time-spot
story: The Perseid meteor shower is expected to peak before dawn on Thursday as the Earth passes through a cloud of cometary dust - producing up to  meteors every hour.If skies are clear, the display of celestial fireworks should be visible across the UK from about midnight tonightuntil .am UK time on Thursday, August  - according to astronomers at Royal Observatory Greenwich.What are the Perseids The astronomical event is associated with the dusty debris left by Comet Swt-Tuttle, which orbits the sun once every  years.The meteoroids from the comet, mostly no bigger than a grain of sand, burn up as they hit the Earthrsquos atmosphere at  miles per second to produce a shooting stream of light in the sky.Peak temperatures can reach anywhere from ,C to ,C as they speed across the sky.The meteors are called Perseids because they seem to dart out of the constellation Perseus.The meteor shower began on July  and will continue to be visible until August .What have astronomers said Anna Ross, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said the best time to spot the meteors is between midnight and .am on Thursday, when up to  meteors or ldquoshooting stars will be visible per hour, which is more than one every second.She told the PA news agency: ldquoThis makes the Perseids one of the most impressive meteor showers of the year.ldquoDuring the peak night of the shower, you will be able to find it in the north-east of the sky, getting higher throughout the night.ldquoYou donrsquot have to be able to see Perseus to spot meteors, however, as they will be moving away from the radiant across the whole sky in every direction.To make the most of the meteors, Ms Ross said observers should avoid well-lit and built-up areas and try to find an unobstructed view to the east.She added: ldquoFind a dark area and allow around  minutes for your eyes adapt to the dark.ldquoAs meteors move quite fast across the sky itrsquos best to look up without using telescopes or binoculars so you can see as much of the sky as possible.How regular will the meteors be The Perseids are one of the more active meteor showers on stargazersrsquo calendars, producing an average of between  and  shooting stars an hour at their peak.The shower in rsquos was especially active, delivering up to  meteors an hour at its height.While the shooting stars this year wonrsquot be quite as regular, stargazers can still expect to see around  of them an hour.Do I need special equipment to see the Perseids Meteor showers are typically visible with the naked eye, so no special equipment is needed, but those in rural areas with minimal light pollution will have a clearer view.Heading out to a dark spot is the best plan of action, but stargazers should allow around  minutes for their eyes to become accustomed to the dark.Patience is also a virtue, with shooting stars tending to appear in clusters, followed by a lull.The meteors will appear to come from the direction of the Perseus constellation in the north eastern part of the sky, although they should be visible from any point.A cloudy night could still scupper your chances of spotting any meteors, however, so keep your eye on weather forecasts.

title: confident-borders-schools-safe-says-council-chief
story: THE leader of Scottish Borders Council says she has "every confidence" that schools have been made safe amid the coronavirus pandemic.Yesterdaypupils ed to the classroom for the first time since March.And Shona Haslam believes all of the necessary measures were introduced before reopening.The member for Tweeddale East said: ldquoThis has been an extremely challenging time for us all and I know there is understandable anxiety in households across the Borders as our children and young peopleto school this week.ldquoAs a parent myself, I have experienced many of these within my own family."However, I have also seen just how hard staff teams from a range of services across the council have been working to make all our settings as safe as they can be, and have every confidence that this has been achieved.The local authority says part of the first few weeks of school will used to "help pupils with the transition back to the classroom".Mrs Haslam added: ldquoWe are extremely grateful to all our parents and carers for their support and co-operation throughout the past five months, not least with the requirement for home learning."Part of the adjustment that will be required over these next weeks will be supporting pupils with the transition back to classroom based learning in general, while taking into account the challenges that the pandemic has brought us.ldquoAdditional support will also be provided for those attending a school for the first time for P pupils and to help our new S pupils with their transition to secondary school.ldquoGoing forward, every effort will be made to make the school day and week as effective as is possible for everyone, while accepting that in keeping everyone safe it will be dferent to previous arrangements."I would ask for your continued co-operation and support for our staff as we do our best to achieve this.

title: pm-northern-ireland-outline-first-stage-anniversary-plan
story: Prime Minister Boris Johnson will outline the first stage of plans to mark the centenary of Northern Irelandrsquos foundation during a visit to the country on Thursday.A forum and historical advisory  will work alongside the Government to commemorate the anniversary.Northern Ireland was created in May  following the partition of Ireland.The Prime Minister said: ldquoAs we mark  years title: education-secretary-rules-teachers-grading-used-exam-results

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: covid-19-recovery-queen-margaret-universitys-new-plan
story: Professionals educated in many of its key areas, from health sciences to the creative arts and social sciences, have already played key roles in tackling the pandemic.As the university launched its new Strategic Plan, which outlined its goals for the next five years, it was stressed that they would also be ldquovital to the global recovery.Highlighted were the graduates and staff who could already be found in positions all across the world, influencing policy, and enhancing society, culture and the economy. The university aimed to continue ldquoto make a real and immediate dference in the world, in keeping with its values.The strategy described how the university would contribute to societyrsquos ldquorecovery and recalibration following the coronavirus pandemic.It also set out how QMUrsquos ldquoperson-centred approach to learning made it ldquostand out from other universities, along with its ldquodistinctive academic portfolio and a focus on making society better.Through teaching, research and innovation, the university would further develop its work enabling people to ldquoheal, nurture, care and communicate, as well as inspire them to build and rebuild businesses, find solutions to real-le issues and to support communities. title: love-first-sight-couple-toast-golden-anniversary
story: Norman and Sophia Taylor enjoyed a socially distanced golden wedding anniversary, due to the Covid- restrictions, at their home on North Grange Avenue on July  with their three children.Northumbrian-born Norman, who turned  on June , met Sophia, , in Prestonpans Royal British Legion in , saying it was ldquolove at first sight and ldquoeyes over a dance floor.The pair married shortly afterwards at Prestonpans Register Office and then went on to travel the world due to Normanrsquos job as a fitter and turner, a trade he learned in the Merchant Navy.The family travelled across Britain between  and . They then stayed in Africa between  and , including Zambia, with the children attending public school in South Africa.However, Sophia started to feel homesick so moved back to Prestonpans in .Norman then got a job in Libya, working four weeks away and then being back at home for four weeks. He worked in this job for the rest of his career, retiring  years ago.During his working le, Norman was also a delivery driver.However, after his retirement he took on the role as a golf caddy at Muirfield, near Gullane.Prestonpans-born Sophia, as Cissie to her friends, worked as a barmaid, including at the former Lady Susan pub in Prestonpans.When Norman married Sophia, she had three children from a previous marriage: Richard, now aged , Charles, , and Eileen, .Their grandson Kal, described as the ldquoapple of their eye, was born in  and was ldquospoiled rotten according to Sophia.Norman and Sophia have sadly been in poor health recently, with Norman suffering a heart attack this year.However, he still makes an effort to visit the Legion in Prestonpans twice a week, every Monday and Friday.When the Legionrsquos beer garden re-opened and Norman was able to go back to his favourite bar, Richard said it was ldquothe first time I have seen a smile on his face for months.Norman says the secret to a long marriage is ldquothe we is always right.Richard added: ldquoThey are totally in love. Irsquove never seen my mum and dad fight and my dad has never risen his voice once. My dad is an absolute gentleman and they absolutely dote on each other.

title: ufo-special-seven-strangest-unexplained-sightings-scotlands-skies
story: Three declassied videos newly released by the Pentagon showing US Navy pilots encountering "unidentied aerial phenomena" ndash or what the rest of us might call UFOs ndash has helped stoke further intrigue about what mysterious objects may be traversing our skies.Theres been a flurry of unexplained sightings reported around the globe ndash in recent months Belgium has recorded its highest number since the countrys famed "UFO wave"  years ago.Scotland is no stranger to a stellar UFO story either. In May, an Airdrie supermarket worker took photographs that he claimed showed a strange blueish-green "flying saucer" and a diamond-shaped cluster of "neon beams" while walking home from work.Here, we look atsome of our favourite tales of strange sightings in the sky.Seven of Scotlands strangest UFO sightings:West Lothian: A close encounterForestry worker Robert Taylor, below, found himself at the heart of one of Scotlands most famous UFO mysteries when he stumbled across a "a huge flying dome" in a woodland clearing near Dechmont Law in Livingston on November , .As he approached the hovering object, two spheres, each about three feet wide with protruding metal spikes "similar to sea mines", dropped down and raced towards him.Members of the British UFO Research Association National Conference with Robert Taylor at the site he saw a UFO near Livingston, West Lothian, in Taylor claimed to have experienced an acrid smell and the sensation of being dragged. He lost consciousness.When Taylor awoke, disorientated and with a throbbing headache, the objects were gone.His trousers were ripped in peculiar fashion, and there were grazes on his legs and chin.Robert Taylor witnessed a huge flying dome near Dechmont Law in West Lothian on November , Police who accompanied Taylor back to the site found "ladder-shaped marks" in the soil where the craft was said to have hovered, and further marks following the path of the mine-like objects.While it would later be suggested that he had suffered an epileptic seizure, mini-stroke or hallucinated after ingesting deadly nightshade berries, Taylor, who died in , never sought publicity or financial gain ndash and always stood by every word of his account.The case remains unique in British history as the only example of a UFO sighting becoming the subject of a criminal investigation.The Falkirk Triangle: Scotlands UFO capitalThe phenomenon known as the "Falkirk Triangle" ndash which includes Bonnybridge and Camelon ndash first began to gain attention in  with the area laying claim to around  sightings a year.A family out for a walk on a March evening in  spoke of witnessing a basketball-sized blue light hovering on the back road from Hallglen to Bonnybridge and claimed to hear a sound similar to a "door opening" followed by a "howl" .A video of an orange oval light above Falkirk, changing shape to becoming a white disc ndash the classic "flying saucer" shape ndash then disappearing suddenly was captured in October . The clip went viral worldwide.Billy Buchanan photographed in UFO hotspot Bonnybridge. Picture: Gordon Terris The HeraldReported sightings became so prolic that councillor Billy Buchanan, now the Falkirk provost, has lobbied three prime ministers ndash David Cameron, Tony Blair and John Major ndash over the years, asking that an investigation be launched .While many of the eerie accounts ndash which range from seeing "big, black and cigar-shaped" objects to "a bright light criss-crossed by stripes of dferent colours" ndash are thought to be misidentications caused by planes, satellites, weather balloons or planets, some simply cant be explained.One theory posited by ufologists is that the Falkirk Triangle could contain a window into another dimension, other worlds, the past or the future. We will leave you to draw your own conclusions.Blairgowrie: Scotlands earliest UFO A bizarre incident in Perthshire was reported in the Annual Register of . It described a pyramid-shaped object over the River Ericht that moved "with great speed and disappeared a little above Blairgowrie", leaving a trail of destruction that included a partly destroyed house and bridge.The area surrounding the town is said to be another hotbed of UFO activity, with reports of strange balls of light in the sky and the location of Scotlands first ever crop circle in .Blairgowrie couple Sid and Gwen Freeman experienced a series of unsettling encounters during April , including a UFO hovering over their garden and a visit from  men dressed in black.Glasgow: Floating entities and a flying railway carriageIn the west end of Glasgow two curious incidents ndash  years apart ndash were reported within the same, small geographic area. The first, in , was at Belhaven Terrace where children playing outside were terried by several entities floating above the ground dressed in long white clothes.In nearby Westbourne Gardens, in , a resident said he watched a silver disc-shaped object move towards his flat window and hover ft above the ground. Witnesses in two nearby flats corroborated his account of events." alt"East Lothian Courier: Have you spotted a UFO over Scotland  Get in touch! " class"editor-image"Have you spotted a UFO over Scotland  Get in touch! Across the city, a man waiting at a bus stop on Menock Road saw what he claimed looked like a railway carriage-shaped object passing ft above his head.The incident took place in December , with the witness reporting being able to see three windows at the front and a glimpse of swirling yellow smoke inside. Afterwards, he described a sensation of time standing still while watching it.Prestwick airport: An unexplained radar blipA series of files released by the Ministry of Defence in  revealed details of what has been dubbed the "Prestwick Airport incident", where an air traffic controller tracked a fast-moving and unexplained flying object on radar.The event, recorded in February , sparked an extensive investigation by RAF air defence staff who impounded radar tapes. However, a report concluded that no additional evidence could be found to corroborate what the air traffic controller had spotted.In August , a member of the public in West Kilbride wrote to the Ministry of Defence to report an a "fluorescent green UFO, saucer shaped" that was "harassing" a plane near Prestwick Airport.Have you spotted a UFO  Get in touchThe A Abduction: Missing hoursTravelling along the A near Harperrig Reservoir in West Lothian on August , , Garry Wood and Colin Wright saw a two-tiered, disc-shaped object above the road.According to their testimony, Wood put his foot down on the accelerator and as they passed beneath the UFO, it appeared to emit a "curtain of white light". The car began shuddering and they emerged to find themselves driving on the wrong side of the road.When Wood and Wright arrived in the South Lanarkshire village of Tarbrax, where they were due to drop off a satellite TV system, they discovered that several hours were unaccounted for. Afterwards they underwent hypnosis sessions, with both men recalling an alien abduction scenario and being subjected to a medical-type examination.Dunfermline: Anglers unexpected catchA metallic disc-shaped craft was caught on camera as it hovered above Craigluscar Reservoir near Dunfermline, Fe, on February , .Ian Macpherson, a member of the local angling club and a keen artist, was taking photographs to assist with a painting he was working on. He was first alerted to something out of the ordinary by a humming noise, similar to that from high voltage power lines.Macpherson describes a sudden uneasy feeling as he turned towards the water to see the object coming towards him. He stood frozen, watching it for more than  minutes.According to his statement: "The craft came close enough for me to see that it was definitely metallic and had several points of dfused light on its underside, inside a darker coloured rim."It was only as the disc flew off at high speed that Macpherson felt able to raise his camera and take two photographs. He said: "The crafts acceleration was phenomenal ndash by the time Id wound the film on between the two shots, it was a mere dot in the sky."By his own admission, Macpherson had no interest in the subject of UFOs. Subsequent checks with the RAF, airports and the police, confirmed no known air traffic at the time.

title: 12-natural-wonders-scotland-must-visit-lifetime
story: Narrowing down a list of favourites was no easy task, but wersquove given it a bash, bringing together a mix of well-known spots and lesser-visited gems deserving of more column inches.If you are heading out to explore this weekend, herersquos some mesmerising and memorable locations courtesy of Mother Nature.Here are  natural wonders of Scotland:Eshaness, ShetlandYou can feel the raw power of nature pulsating from what has been described as one of the most high energy coastlines in the world. Battered by the colossal force of the North Atlantic, this corner of Shetland is home to caves, stacks, arches, blowholes and geos .The peninsula is formed from the remains of the extinct Eshaness volcano, dating back some  to  million years. The clfs you see today cut through the flank of the volcano, revealing layers of lava and pyroclastic rock blasted from its crater.Visit shetland.orgAn Lochan Uaine, Glenmore, near AviemoreThe emerald waters of An Lochan Uaine, aka The Green Lochan, in Glenmore Forest Park are an enchanting sight to behold. According to legend, the distinctive hue came about when pixies washed their clothes here.Scientic bods will tell you itrsquos more likely down to the algae generated by decomposing wood that lines the lochanrsquos floor or a fluke of the light reflecting off the trees around its edges. Pah, spoilsports. I mean, who do you believe  Keep your eyes peeled for pixies on the gentle walk through the ancient Caledonian pines.Visit forestryandland.gov.scotFingalrsquos Cave, StaffaThis mysterious sea cave on the uninhabited Hebridean island of Staffa looks intricately hand-carved rather than formed by a quirk of cooling lava. The ftcavern has tremendous acoustics.Fingalrsquos Cave gained its moniker from the eponymous hero of a poem by the th-century Scots poet-historian James Macpherson .Composer Felix Mendelssohn wrote an overture in its honour, artist J M W Turner has painted it and author Jules Verne mentions it in three novels, including the famed Journey to the Centre of the Earth.Visit staffatoursBow Fiddle Rock, near Portknockie, MorayTherersquos no big secret to how this incredible natural formation got its name: it looks uncannily like a bow perched atop the strings of a fiddle. Located just off the coast from Portknockie, the distinctive shape was forged over time as the force of the waves eroded a type of rock called Cullen Quartzite.It is a place that you can photograph a hundred times and each one captures something slightly dferent ndash be it the colour of the sky, the swell of the sea or a hint of brooding atmosphere. Bow Fiddle Rock forms part of the North East  route as it traverses the Moray Firth coastline.Visit northeast and visitscotlandFortingall Yew, PerthshireThe Fortingall Yew, pictured, found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, is among the oldest trees in Europe. There is some debate about its age. Modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old.Fortingall YewAccording to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child. More recently this legend has been credited as a hoax devised by Sir Donald Currie, a shipping magnate who bought the Glenlyon Estate in .Visit visitscotlandOrkneyrsquos sea stacksThe rugged clfs and coastline around Orkney boast a raft of spectacular sea stacks with The Old Man of Hoy, a fthigh monolith of towering, red sandstone perhaps its most famous. That said, he it has many handsome siblings, such as The Needle on Hoyrsquos south-west coast.The Old Man of Hoy. Picture: Cameron McNeish Scottish Walks MagazineTherersquos the striking Yesnaby Castle on the west mainland, and North Gaulton Castle which the eagle-eyed may recognise from a  car advert for Rover. Further up the mainland coast, just north of the Bay of Skaill, therersquos the brilliantly named Stack orsquo Roo.Visit orkneyGalloway Forest Dark Sky Park, Dumfries and GallowayWhen did you last see the Milky Way  For those of us residing in urban areas, itrsquos more likely we are familiar with the sweet treat found in corner shops than the bright band arching across the night sky. Galloway Forest Park is a perfect spot to go stargazing.Very few people live within its  square miles area which means the nights are jet black. A clutch of planets and more than , twinkling stars are visible with the naked eye. The Perseid meteor shower reaches its peak from August  to  this year. Top tip: take a sun lounger because it saves on neck craning.Visit scottishdarkskyobservatory and forestryandland.gov.scotThe Cuillin, SkyeRed or black  Itrsquos almost impossible to choose, like being asked to pick a favourite child. The Cuillin is made up of two ranges ndash the Black Cuillin and the Red Cuillin ndash separated by Glen Sligachan.They were formed by volcanic and glacial activity, then further sculpted by weathering over the millennia to emerge looking very dferent indeed.The jagged outlines of the Black Cuillin are the remains of a magma chamber belonging to a giant volcano and comprised largely of rough gabbro rock, while the rounded humps of the Red Cuillin are made mainly of granite.Visit visitscotlandCorryvreckan Whirlpool, ArgyllA perilous, swirling vortex with a formidable reputation. The Corryvreckan Whirlpool, between Jura and Scarba, is infamous for strong tidal currents and standing waves that make it one of the most dangerous stretches within the British Isles. At times, the mighty roar is so loud that it can be heard  miles away. The whirlpool is the third-largest in the world and caused by an unusual underwater topography in the Gulf of Corryvreckan that creates the so-called speckled cauldron. There are boat tours available for those brave enough to venture here.Visit craignishcruises and juraboattoursGrey Marersquos Tail, Moffat, DumfriesshireTalk about a beautul image. Evenyou have never seen this thundering waterfall in the flesh, you can imagine what it looks like ndash the swishing grey tail of a mare ndash as it cascades down ftwhere the Tail Burn flows from Loch Skeen into the Moffat Water Valley.Grey Mares Tail. Picture: National Trust for ScotlandIts majesty was celebrated in verse by Sir Walter Scott who wrote in Marmion about the frothing water as being as ldquowhite as the snowy chargerrsquos tail. There is historical evidence in the nearby area of Iron Age settlers and the Covenanters who sought sanctuary in the th century.Visit nts.org.ukBass Rock, East LothianSure, itrsquos a big lump of rock covered in bird poo, but, in geological and natural history terms, the Bass Rock is a stunner. The steep-sided volcanic plug rises ftout of the Firth of Forth.It is regarded as a Site of Special Scientic Interest and is renowned for its vast gannet colony ndash some , at the peak of the breeding season ndash hailed by Sir David Attenborough as ldquoone of the  wildle wonders of the world.The Bass Rock has been a retreat for early Christian hermits, welcomed royal visits and served as a notorious gaol for religious and political prisoners.Visit seabird.orgThe beaches of Sanday, OrkneySanday by name, sandy by nature. Seen from the air you would be forgiven for imagining you had flown through a tear in the space-time continuum and were seeing a tropical island in the Caribbean or South Pacic rather than Scotland. Bays and beaches, white sands and turquoise waters abound.Among the many gems on Sanday is Tresness, a sliver of a peninsula with ine dunes sandwiched between a sheltered tidal bay to the west and the North Sea on the east. Therersquos also the gorgeous Whitemill Bay, Lopness, Sty Wick, Scuthvie Bay and Sandquoy ndash the list goes on.Visit orkney

title: lights-vandalised-andy-scotts-dunbear-statue
story: The steel sculpture, which features a bear standing on its hind legs and is located just off the A, near the Spott Roundabout on the edge of Dunbar, was unveiled last December.A post on social media revealed that lights next to the sculpture, which measures  feet in height, had been damaged.It reads: ldquoWe are conscious that a number of lights have been deliberately damaged at the DunBear sculpture and thanks to those for reporting this to us.ldquoWe have an engineer out looking at this.ldquoThe sculpture is very much part of the community and we would be gratefulyou see anyone damaging it that this is reported to the police.The artwork was created by Andy Scott, the same man behind The Kelpies, and is a tribute to Dunbar-born John Muir, who would go on to become a key figure in the formation of the US national parks.
